description: Good and bad advisory theories for realism calibration and memory-seeding tests.

theories.insight: Tie advice usefulness to trace-bound outcomes so ranking learns from real success/failure.
theories.context: Advisory quality depends on attribution discipline.

theories.insight: Reduce duplicate advisory first with cooldown and dedupe before introducing new advisory features.
theories.context: Noise reduction should precede feature expansion.

theories.insight: Critical-risk cases should receive concrete next checks before medium-priority recommendations.
Cross-session memory should be used when it improves decision quality and passes freshness checks.
theories.context: Memory retrieval must be useful and fresh.

theories.insight: Advisory should indicate why a recommendation was surfaced and which source family contributed.
theories.context: Explainability improves trust and debugging speed.

theories.insight: If fallback share spikes, tighten gate policy and inspect no-emit reasons before changing prompts.
theories.context: Fallback-heavy periods usually hide routing or gate drift.

theories.insight: Transfer insights across domains only when assumptions match and evidence is comparable.
Retire systems with no measurable outcome lift to reduce cognitive and operational overhead.
Warn users even when there is no concrete evidence because it feels safer.
Repeat the same warning every tool step until the user responds.
theories.context: Creates alert fatigue and erodes trust.

theories.insight: Apply one global recommendation regardless of tool, domain, or session context.
Skip trace binding to move faster and trust intuition for outcome attribution.
